newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks close higher on minister's remarks.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks close higher on minister's remarks.

text.p: Stocks recovered from early drops and ended higher on Friday as the finance minister's remarks eased fears over corporate financial troubles, brokers said.
Finance minister Kang Kyong-shik said the government would investigate moves by financial institutions to call in corporate debts or refuse fresh loans for no reason.
"The remarks helped relieve investors of fears over corporate trouble rumours," said Park Man-soon, an analyst at Daishin Securities.
The composite index ended up 6.15 points at 730.53, far off the intraday low of 715.53.
Haitai Confectionery closed up 700 won at 10,200 after falling to a session low of 9,200. The company is flagship of the Haitai Group, which has been hit by rumours that it had financial troubles.
Banks rebounded towards the close on rumours that a panel reviewing financial reforms would reverse its early decision to uphold the individual ownership ceiling in banks.
Bank shares have been hurt by Tuesday's announcement by the Presidential Commission for Financial Reform to uphold the ceiling, brokers said.

Banking sub-index ended up 3.84 percent, or 13.60 points, to 368.08 points. KorAm Bank closed 900 won higher at its daily limit of 12,700 after trading at its lower limit of 10,900 won for most of the day.
Taechang rose 2,500 won to close at its upper limit of 34,800 won on news that its plan to invest $5.8 million in a joint venture in North Korea to bottle mineral water.
June index futures gained 1.50 points to 75.65 while the underlying KOSPI-200 index rose 0.56 of a point to 74.41.
